title: 109_hr5939
content: The Act may be cited as the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" and includes provisions related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code by adding a new offense, Sec. 2339E, which punishes individuals who cause death in the course of committing a terrorist offense. The term 'terrorist offense' is defined as a felony offense that is a Federal crime of terrorism or an offense under specific sections. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" adds a new offense, Sec. 2339E, to Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. It punishes individuals who cause death while committing a terrorist offense, defined as a felony offense that is a Federal crime of terrorism or an offense under specific sections. The table of sections is amended to reflect this new item. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense, Sec. 2339E, in Chapter 113B of title 18, US Code, punishing individuals for causing death during a terrorist offense. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends various sections of the United States Code to include death penalty provisions for offenses related to nuclear weapons, missile systems, atomic weapons, and radiological dispersal devices. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" adds death penalty provisions for offenses involving radiological dispersal devices and the variola virus in the United States Code. SEC. 4 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" increases penalties for certain offenses by amending the United States Code to extend prison terms. SEC. 5 modernizes the state of mind requirement for specific offenses. SEC. 5 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Section 2339C of title 18, US Code, by changing the state of mind requirement to "knowingly". SEC. 6 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" increases penalties for providing material support to terrorist groups and receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. SEC. 7 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" focuses on denying federal benefits to convicted terrorists. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, to deny Federal benefits to individuals convicted of Federal crimes of terrorism. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code by adding a new section to deny Federal benefits to individuals convicted of Federal crimes of terrorism. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" adds new provisions to Title 18, United States Code, including denial of Federal benefits to terrorists and amendments to wiretap predicates and military training offenses.
